title: ULM focused on back half of the season
text:
ULM focused on back half of the season Adam Hunsucker , ahunsucker@thenewsstar.com 6:38 p.m. CDT October 20, 2015 The current record of the seven teams remaining on ULM’s schedule is a combined 11-30. Idaho moved to 2-4 on the season after beating Troy last Saturday. (Photo: Emerald McIntyre/ULM Photo Services) 20 CONNECT 3 TWEET LINKEDIN COMMENT EMAIL MORE 
Todd Berry isn’t naïve enough to think the Warhawks haven’t looked ahead at what’s left on the schedule. 
Berry hasn’t, or at the very least won’t admit to it, but did acknowledge in his Tuesday press conference that ULM played its best five opponents of the season in September and October. 
Any optimism surrounding a 1-5 football team is — and should be — guarded at best, but it’s fair to call the remaining portion of ULM’s schedule manageable. 
Starting this Saturday at Idaho, the remaining seven teams ULM will see have a combined record of 11-30 at this point in 2015. 
“I mentioned the other day as I was looking at the first part of our schedule it was very frontloaded,” Berry said. “But what we need to do, and this is always the case, is to prepare the best you can regardless of the opponent and as hard as you can. 
“The great thing about football is you have the opportunity to clear out the demons and play another game” Injuries continue to decimate ULM's roster 
If demons are what determines wins and losses, then there isn’t a team in the country in need of an exorcism more than the Warhawks. 
It’s been over a month since ULM won a football game, and that was against FCS Nicholls State. The Warhawks have yet to beat an FBS opponent so far this season. 
Last Saturday provided the latest indignation for long-suffering fans who opted for the exits at Malone Stadium instead of sitting through a 59-14 loss to Appalachian State — ULM’s worst home loss in the program’s FBS era. 
The team hasn’t been immune from the talk outside of the program, much of which centers on Berry’s job security. 
“A win would do a whole lot for our confidence and probably put everything to rest and help people feel good about this place,” tight end Harley Scioneaux said. “We’ve played hard each week but we’ve had to go back to the drawing board and look at a couple things.” Wickstrom not ready to give up on ULM's season 
The first adjustment ULM made this week started at the top, where Berry relinquished the play calling to assistant head coach and offensive coordinator Steve Farmer for the Idaho game. 
Berry said he thought giving up calling plays for one week was in the best interest of the team and would allow him to be more involved with the defense. 
Despite a losing streak that’s now at four-straight games, Berry said he’s proud of the way ULM has handled many adverse situations this season, including all the injury woes and the sudden death of backup quarterback Daniel Fitzwater. 
“I told the team on Sunday one of the toughest things for a football team to do, and that’s why we do it, is to go over to your student section and your band after a game. When you win there’s an elation that comes with success but when you lose you have to face the music,” Berry said. 
“Sunday there weren’t any heads down. Their heads were up kind of owning this and that’s part of being accountable.”
